column5: E J Collins; B L Booth Jr; V Cerundolo
column8: Extensive alanine substitutions increase binding affinity of an influenza nucleoprotein peptide to HLA-Aw68 and do not abrogate peptide-specific CTL recognition.
column20: Alanine substitutions were performed to determine key residues.  Substitution of the anchor position T2 did not generate significant changes in stability of the MHC complex.  Substitution of the R9 anchor generated a significant reduction on the stability of the complex.
column67: The temperature at which 50% of the protein was denatured was determined.

column5: E J Collins; B L Booth Jr; V Cerundolo
column8: Extensive alanine substitutions increase binding affinity of an influenza nucleoprotein peptide to HLA-Aw68 and do not abrogate peptide-specific CTL recognition.
column20: This epitope is a variant of the naturally occurring influenza nucleoprotein epitope at positions 91-99, with an alanine residue inserted between the P and I residues.
column67: The temperature at which 50% of the protein was denatured was determined.

column5: M L Silver; K C Parker; D C Wiley
column8: Reconstitution by MHC-restricted peptides of HLA-A2 heavy chain with beta 2-microglobulin, in vitro.
column67: The assay is gel filtration of reconstituted HLA-complex; absorbance of eluted fractions was measured.

column5: M L Silver; K C Parker; D C Wiley
column8: Reconstitution by MHC-restricted peptides of HLA-A2 heavy chain with beta 2-microglobulin, in vitro.
column67: The assay is gel filtration of reconstituted HLA-complex; absorbance of eluted fractions was measured.

column5: M L Silver; H C Guo; J L Strominger; D C Wiley
column8: Atomic structure of a human MHC molecule presenting an influenza virus peptide.
column67: The complex between HLA-Aw68 and the peptide revealed that peptide residues P1, P2, P3, and P9 are substantially buried in the antigen-binding cleft, while the central peptide residues from P4 to P8 are exposed and could be recognized by T-cell receptors.

column5: G Missale; A Redeker; J Person; P Fowler; S Guilhot; H J Schlicht; C Ferrari; F V Chisari
column8: HLA-A31- and HLA-Aw68-restricted cytotoxic T cell responses to a single hepatitis B virus nucleocapsid epitope during acute viral hepatitis.
column20: Analog of natural epitope with alanine substitution at residue L143.
column67: Peptide containing an alanine substitution at residue L143 did not compete with the natural epitope, HBcAg141-151, for binding to HLA-Aw68, suggesting that L143 is likely involved in the interaction of HBcAg141-151 with HLA-Aw68.

column5: G Missale; A Redeker; J Person; P Fowler; S Guilhot; H J Schlicht; C Ferrari; F V Chisari
column8: HLA-A31- and HLA-Aw68-restricted cytotoxic T cell responses to a single hepatitis B virus nucleocapsid epitope during acute viral hepatitis.
column20: Analog of natural epitope with alanine substitution at residue T146.
column67: Peptide containing an alanine substitution at residue T146 did compete with the natural epitope, HBcAg141-151, for binding to HLA-Aw68, suggesting that T146 is not likely involved in the interaction of HBcAg141-151 with HLA-Aw68.

column5: E J Collins; D N Garboczi; M N Karpusas; D C Wiley
column6: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A
column8: The three-dimensional structure of a class I major histocompatibility complex molecule missing the alpha 3 domain of the heavy chain.
column67: The MHC molecule used had its alpha3 domain proteolytically removed. Unambiguous electron density was observed for the peptide except for the side chains of P7 and P9, which extend into solvent and may be disordered. Also, P9 contacts the beta2-m domain of another molecule in the crystal.

column5: H C Guo; T S Jardetzky; T P Garrett; W S Lane; J L Strominger; D C Wiley
column8: Different length peptides bind to HLA-Aw68 similarly at their ends but bulge out in the middle.
column16: unknown protein eluted from human MHC allele
column20: The epitope is from a collection of bound, endogenous peptides.The epitope sequence comes from models of residues E-V-A and A-R that were built for peptide positions P1, P2, P3 at the N-terminus and PC-1, PC carboxy terminal, respectively.
column67: The structure represents the average image from the collection of bound peptides of 9, 10, and 11 amino acids eluted from HLA-Aw68. There is clear electron density for the first three and last two residues of the peptides, but not for any of the in between residues. The middle part of the peptide density is sparse and unconnected, presumable representing an average of diverse conformations and/or length. Models of residues E-V-A and A-R were built for peptide positions P1, P2, P3 and PC-1, PC, respectively.
